entry.p: Reading a book on Matsuo Bashō has renewed my interest in ultra-short poems. The best-known form here is haiku, which in Japanese consists of three sections of 5, 7, and 5 syllables each. The most famous haiku is probably this one written by Bashō in 1686:
entry.blockquote: furuike ya kawazu tobikomu mizu no oto
entry.p: It's often translated as something like this:
entry.blockquote:
ancient pond
a frog jumps in
water's sound
entry.p: Because English has many short words (compare "frog" to "kawazu" or "jumps in" to "tobikomu"), it's possible to write even more concise poems in English than in most other languages. Although I never thought I'd consider haiku to be wordy, compare a few 5-7-5 verses to a few 3-4-3 verses:
entry.blockquote:
thundering waters
at this distance only seen
make a cooling mist

see the mist?
waters thunder
far away

cicadas buzzing
in well-watered cottonwoods
down in the ravine

down below
cicadas buzz
in the trees

in this early snow
faded flowers of summer
plastered on the ground

early snow
summer blossoms
plastered ground
entry.p: Or this one (appropriate for my collection of urban haiku):
entry.blockquote:
a couple huddles
with a single umbrella
waiting for the bus

he and she
one umbrella
bus stop bench
entry.p: I rather like the even more concise, evocative 3-4-3 format with its mere 10 syllables. I'm not sure if it has a name (most poets just call it a haiku), but "toku" is a possibility (I think that would be Japanese for "ten-verse", but I've never studied Japanese so I'm only guessing).
Oh, and mimicking Bashō here is a haiku on Henry David Thoreau:
entry.blockquote:
Walden pond
Thoreau jumps in
water's sound
